intro: Salvia sonchifolia, commonly known as common sage, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–90 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges. Its flowers are tubular and clustered in whorled inflorescences, usually in shades of purple or blue. Salvia sonchifolia is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used traditionally in herbal medicine.
